Headline.Para: THE BOTTOM LINE; How businesses can tune into AI

LeadPara.Para: FROM turning driverless cars into a reality to personalising healthcare based on genetic information, artificial intelligence has opened doors to new possibilities, paving the way for businesses of the future. A recent study by Vanson Bourne revealed that AI is actively used by 80 per cent of enterprises globally, with the Asia-Pacific leading the pack at 48 per cent, and this figure is growing rapidly. Policymakers in the region are also throwing their weight behind the push for AI: Singapore will see S$150 million put into its AI national programme, while Thailand now seeks to shore up its robotics and automation capabilities with a US$6 billion investment.

By 2020, AI will be built into every new software product, according to Gartner. The question is therefore no longer whether to implement AI, but how to leverage AI effectively to deliver business results.

TailParas.Para: It's no surprise that many companies are jumping on board the AI bandwagon. Combined with machine learning (ML), AI is able to manage tasks at an unrivalled speed, and can be programmed to conduct problem-solving in an unbiased, data-backed process. Mining gems within large pools of data, be it structured or unstructured, AI is able to pull valuable insights that could potentially transform the business, while lowering cost in the long run.

Beyond automating day-to-day operations and administrative processes, AI allows highly trained technical resources to be redeployed to more critical, strategic parts of the business. For example, IT staff traditionally focused on storing and securing data can be freed up to focus on using the very same data to innovate and drive business growth.

For those planning to implement AI or ML projects, advances in GPU technology have largely eliminated the compute bottleneck that used to hold these projects back. Still, despite being implemented ubiquitously, massively parallel, highly performant GPUs are severely underutilised, suggesting that companies are eager to start AI projects but are still figuring out how to make the most out of their hefty investments.

The adoption of AI is only the beginning, and a solid IT strategy is needed to unleash the full potential of AI. The challenge today lies in feeding data analysis pipelines central to AI fast enough for AI projects to perform at maximum efficiency, and it's time we started paying attention to the critical role data plays in successful deployment of AI.

As large, high-quality datasets are needed to ensure accuracy in deep learning models, organisations looking to implement AI should focus on data collection and cleaning first. Across the Asia-Pacific, data consumption in the coming years is expected to flourish with growth rates as high as 60 per cent per annum. It is therefore important to invest in storage infrastructure capable of supporting today's data volume and velocity across various workloads. This storage layer also needs to be flexible and agile enough to scale linearly and non-disruptively, and deliver uncompromised performance now and in the future.
OUT WITH LEGACY, IN WITH FLASH

Legacy platforms struggle to meet these demanding requirements; data can easily end up in infrastructure siloes at each stage of the AI pipeline, making projects more complex, time-intensive and inflexible. For these reasons, legacy storage is quickly becoming a thing of the past, as modern all-flash platforms take over, bringing together data into a centralised data storage hub and enabling multiple jobs to run simultaneously. This facilitates deep learning and significantly improves the rate at which AI projects develop.

Take the automotive industry for example. Millions of frames are collected from sensors and cameras on autonomous vehicles to train deep neural networks, which are then used to power self-driving technology. As AI is crucial in making safe, driverless cars a reality, flash is required to provide scalability and performance, and facilitating self-driving technology on legacy infrastructure would simply be dangerous and out of the question.

The future of AI is bright, but for it to truly shine, companies should recognise that AI isn't just about deep learning, but deep and continuous learning. A one-off neural network training phase is not enough; many applications require continual fine-tuning based on real data that is being processed.

Organisations would therefore benefit from reviewing their existing storage capacities to ensure that infrastructure is flexible and performant enough to meet the demands of continuous training and data flows. Balancing compute, memory and storage is key to optimising AI workflows, and unlocking the infinite possibilities AI has to offer.
* The writer is regional vice-president, Asia-Pacific and Japan, at Pure Storage.
